title: CTRL0000061473 - Transcribed Interview of Nick Quested, (Apr. 5, 2022)

data.text: SELECT COMMITTEE TO INVESTIGATE THE
JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL
U.S. HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
WASHINGTON, D.C.
INTERVIEW OF: NICK QUESTED
Tuesday, April 5, 2022
Washington, D.C.
The interview in the above matter was held in room 4480 O'Neill House Office
Building, commencing at 10:14 a.m.
Appearances:
For the SELECT COMMITTEE TO INVESTIGATE
THE JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL:
INVESTIGATIVE COUNSEL
INVESTIGATIVE COUNSEL
INVESTIGATIVE COUNSEL
, PROFESSIONAL STAFF MEMBER
INVESTIGATIVE COUNSEL
, PROFESSIONAL STAFF MEMBER
We will go on the record at
10:11 a.m. Eastern Time.
Good morning. This is a transcribed
interview of Mr. Nick Quested, conducted by the U.S.
House Select Committee to investigate the January 6th
attack on the United States Capitol, pursuant to House
Resolution 503.
At this time I'd ask the witness to please
state your full name and spell your last name for the
record.
THE WITNESS. Nicholas Quested. That's
Q-u-e-s-t-e-d.
BY
Q
Thank you, Mr. Quested. This will be a
staff-led interview, and members, of course, may choose
to also ask questions.
In the room today we have
that's me, investigative counsel. We h a v e -
investigative counsel;
counsel;
do not have any members in the room today or present
virtually.
investigative
, professional staff member. We
There is an official reporter transcribing
the record of this interview. Please wait,
Mr. Quested, until each question is completed before
you begin your response, and we will try to wait until
your response is complete before we ask our next
question.
The stenographer cannot record nonverbal
responses, such as shaking your head, so it's important
that you answer each question with an audible verbal
response.
Do you understand that, Mr. Quested?
A
Yes.
Q
We ask that you provide complete answers
based on your best recollection. If the question is
not clear, then please just ask me for a clarification.
And if you do not know the answer to a question that
one of us asks, please just say so.
I also want to remind you that it is unlawful
to deliberately provide false information to Congress.
For this interview, providing false information could
result in criminal penalties for false statements.
Do you understand that?
A
Yes.
Q
Logistically please let us know if you need
any breaks or would like to discuss anything off the
record. There may be several people asking you
questions today, so, again, if you don't understand,
please just simply ask one of us to repeat.
So, Mr. Quested, we're going to start with
some background. Can you please just tell us where you
live, how old you are.
A
I'm 52 years old. I live in New York. I
have a small farm in Upstate New York, in the Hudson
Valley.
Q
What is your educational background?
A
I was educated in London. I came to America
for university. I graduated from NYU with a joint
honors degree in French literature and film.
Q
Mr. Quested?
A
I make documentaries.
Q
Have you always made documentaries?
A
No. I've consistently made documentaries
What do you currently do for a living,
through my career, but I'm probably best known for
directing music videos. I've directed over 100 music
videos for most of the notable rappers there are, from
Dr. Dre to Puffy, to Ice Cube, to Snoop Dagg, to Trick
Daddy, to Trina -- sorry. I have to do that quickly.
My apologies.
Dr. Dre, Nas, Puffy, Trick Daddy, Trina,
Timbaland, Master P, Cash Money.
I can go on for a while.
Q
But what kind of documentaries do you make
A
We do two types of documentaries. We do
now?
reportage documentaries. My partner, Sebastian Junger,
we made a film called Restrepo that was nominated for
an Oscar. We spent 15 months in the Korengal Valley
doing a portrait of the deployment of the 173rd
Airborne. And so we do films like that.
We made a film about a friend and colleague,
Tim Hetherington, who was killed in Libya.
We made a film about traumatic stress called
The Last Patrol.
And then we did two documentaries, one about
the war in Syria and Iraq called Hell of Earth, which
we won a du Pont Award for, and a variety of others.
And -- where we tried to explain in simple terms the
origins of the conflict in Syria and Iraq and the human
cost.
And then we made a film about -- called Blood
on the Wall about the political realities of life in
Mexico at the moment, how Mexico got to where it is,
and creates a parallel between migration and narcotics.
We followed the caravan from Guatemala all the way into
America, and then we followed the opium from the field
to a motel in Downtown Los Angeles.
- c a n you pull up
Exhibit 1, please?
THE WITNESS. The other part is we make films
1O
about public culture, so we have a film coming out this
spread around the world with mixed tapes.
BY
Q
So this is Exhibit 1. This is your bio.
Can you please just scan it real quickly and
let us know if this is --
A
Yeah, that's it.
Q
-- an accurate bio?
A
Yes. It's old, but it's accurate.
Q
Are you still with Goldcrest Films?
A
Goldcrest is my company. It's a family
business.
Q
Okay.
A
Goldcrest is a venerable film production
company. In our library -- as a production company we
would make Gandhi, Chariots of Fire, The Killing
Fields, A Room With a View, Hope and Glory, The
Mission, and most notably or most successfully, All
Dogs Go To Heaven.
Q
Thank you, Mr. Quested.
We can take that down. Awesome.
So let's go now to some of the topics that
are more relevant to January 6.
Did you become acquainted with Mr. Tarrio in
December 2020, Enrique Tarrio, that is?
A
Yes.
Q
Could you tell us how you got connected with
Mr. Tarrio?
A
I was connected through a colleague of mine,
Kathryn Gilbert. Kathryn Gilbert's husband is Josh
Goldstein. Josh Goldstein is a former SEAL. He has
extensive Tier 1 contacts. Kathryn came up with a
number for Enrique that I called.
Why were you interested in getting connected
Q
with Mr. Tarrio?
A
We were making a film about how America was
so divided when Americans have so much in common. And
we spent some time on the various protests through the
summer and started to see the rise in the acerbic
rhetoric of both sides. And so we felt that we wanted
to try and tell the story in extremis, as in we could
look at Proud Boys and BLM and Antifa and see what
common arguments that they have, or common grievances
they have.
Q
And how did Mr. Tarrio fit into this
documentary or film that you were producing at the
time?
A
Well, Mr. Tarrio is the -- or was the leader
of the Proud Boys at the time. And I thought it was an
interesting, the fact that he's Cuban American and of
darker skin was an interesting irony for a
prate-fascist street militia.
Q
Did Ms. Gilbert or her husband give you any
background on Mr. Tarrio when you reached out to him
the first time?
A
No, I -- no.
Q
So then can you walk us through your first
interaction with Mr. Tarrio. You said you called him.
How did that phone conversation go?
A
It was very informal. He was like, Okay.
Good cool. Come down. I like your film. That was
great.
And so we came down. We agreed to meet on
November 11 outside the Phoenix Hotel where we had an
informal conversation. And then I was with the core
members of the Proud Boys there. There was, you
know --
Q
Sorry to interrupt. Sorry to
Was it November 11 or December 11?
A
Sorry. December 11, sorry.
Q
And approximately when did you make the phone
call to him?
A
late November. Probably before Thanksgiving.
Q
Oh, probably some time towards the end of
Got it. Okay.
So you were saying you met with him, it
sounds like on December 11 --
A
Yes.
Q
-- in Washington, D.C.?
A
Yes.
Q
Okay. Please continue. I'm sorry to cut you
off.
A
No problem.
There was -- so they were drinking outside of
the Phoenix Hotel at a bar called the Dubliner. Yeah,
the Dubliner, I think.
And then they had to bring their own alcohol
because it was COVID restrictions at the time. And it
was, you know, a boisterous affair of, you know -- it
felt like -- it felt like a rugby club at that time.
Q
What were your impressions of Mr. Tarrio when
you first met him in person on December 11th, it sounds
like?
A
My first impression was he was an affirmable,
personable guy. He was not -- he didn't really have an
opinion of us. He was just like, Here, you are. It's
all good.
He introduced us to some of his people and we
had discussions about this. So sort of tried to
establish our bona fide journalistic credentials. Like
we mentioned Restrepo a lot because a lot of them are
veterans, and we try to find commonalty as quickly as
we can with people.
There was a guy from Pittsburgh. I always go
with "Mean" Joe Greene, you know, ball of steel.
That's always a good one.
Q
comment.
A
It's always good.
Q
So at that time with Mr. Tarrio, is it safe
As a Steelers' fan, I appreciate that
to say that your prior films allowed you to build
rapport with him pretty quickly?
A
Absolutely.
Q
So what were you in D.C. for that, I guess,
on December 11th? What did Mr. Tarrio say was going on
inD.C.atthetime?
A
Well, there was going to be a rally the next
day. I'm not quite sure. I mean, I've heard this
rally being called several different things, whether it
be the "Million MAGA 2" or "Stop the Steal." But the
idea was that there was going to be a night march and a
prayer. And then the next day there was going to be a
daytime march and a nighttime march.
There was definitely -- there was definitely
a subtext that the second night march was going to be
more aggressive than the November 14th. They were here
to take back their streets.
Q
So on December 11th it was going to be a
night march and a prayer. And then on December 12 it
was going to be a day march and a night march; is that
correct?
A
Yes.
Q
So was the first event that you attended with
the Proud Boys on December 11th the prayer meeting that
you just mentioned?
A
Yeah. There was a lot of marching around as
well. There wasn't as many Proud Boys as the next day,
but there was quite a few. They tried to walk in a
line down the Mall, generally unsuccessfully. But
there was a lot of walking up and down the Mall.
Q
And I'm going to ask you this question
throughout your interview here today, but what was the
general feeling or mood as you were with the Proud Boys
on December 11th?
A
The general feeling was kind of -- I felt
that -- there was not euphoria, but there was an
excitement to those rallies. Like, people were
positive. I mean, the rhetoric was -- the rhetoric
from Ta rrio was, If you want a war, then you've got
one. We won't be trod on.
You know, the -- it's a -- there's not
much -- he was -- so he was building excitement within
his group. And close to him was -- on that day was
particularly Spaziola and Biggs and Nordean and Zach
Rehl. That was very obvious that they were close. And
also Jeremy Bertino.
Q
And those individuals that you just listed,
did they go to the prayer event on December 11?
A
Yes.
Q
Can you describe just in general what this
prayer meeting consisted of, or prayer/gathering
consisted of?
A
It consisted of a speech from Enrique on the
bullhorn, you know, refusing to talk about the stolen
election and that they wouldn't, they weren't prepared
to take it.
And then it consisted to -- I think -- I
don't remember what the prayer was at night. I
remember the prayer was led by -- during the day, the
next day was led by a guy called Yoda from Colorado,
which was another African American Proud Boy, which was
a bit muddled, the prayer, I felt.
BY
Q
group that he was close to, one of them was Spaziola.
A
Yeah, I have a picture of Spaziola next to
Q
From what you observed, could you describe
him.
You mentioned earlier that part of the core
that relationship? Or were they conversing a lot?
A
No, I think Spaziola was there, was very
supportive. And I didn't see much conversation.
just saw a proximity. I saw a proximity.
Q
But it was clear that they knew each other?
A
Oh, absolutely.
Q
So in the prior meeting you mentioned some of
the things that Tarrio was talking about, but it didn't
sound like there was actually religious content in
that?
A
There was religious content, but I kind of
feel that the religious content is in a -- sort of an
assuagement to -- I don't think it's a core tenet of
their belief. It's like an add-on.
It was particularly notable during his speech
that he waited -- he forgot to mention the 2A aspect to
their struggle. So he just sort of tacked that on in
the end. And you won't take our guns, which I thought
was like, you know, is not obviously not part of his
struggle and just felt it was a buzz point to take off
on his speech.
Q
meeting?
A
So was there actual prayer at this prayer
There was a prayer subsequent to that, a
brief prayer. More like a grace almost.
1O
Got it.
BY
Q
On December 11th -- and I'm also going to ask
you this question throughout -- do you recall
Mr. Tarrio being around or talking to Mr. Roger Stone?
A
Yes. They had a -- Roger Stone came out to
the hotel that's just -- it's close to the Willard. Is
it the Hyatt? It has columns in front of it.
And it was -- it felt like a pep rally.
Roger came out and stood on the -- just where there's
like a planters or something, and addressed the crowd
very briefly. The crowd shouted his name. And it
was --you know, it was a little bizarre, frankly.
Q
We're going to play a clip of what I believe
is the time that Mr. Stone came out with Mr. Tarrio on
December 11. So we're going to play Exhibit 2. And
we're just going to play the first minute of Exhibit 2.
(Video played)
THE WITNESS. There's a Proud Boy, and
there's Tarrio.
While we're playing the
video -THE WITNESS. Sorry.
(Video played)
Thank you.
BY
Q
I believe, Mr. Quested, you were telling us
who was in the video. Can you now list off the folks
that you remember?
First of all, was this the speech that you
remember seeing on December 11?
A
Yes, yes.
I was behind them actually. If you took
three steps back. I think I got in the way of my own
camera. So that was why I sort of stepped back.
Q
Okay. And can you tell us who is around
Mr. Stone at this time?
A
Yes. From left to right, that is Ethan
Nordean, Enrique Tarrio, and then Roger Stone.
Q
And do you know who that is speaking, the
person in this video? Did you know who that was at the
time speaking?
A
No, I don't remember.
Q
Did Mr. Stone actually speak at this event?
A
Briefly. But only with -- probably just to
thank the crowd. I don't recall exactly. I felt the
crowd reacted to him in a very positive way, and I
think he, you know, enjoyed that.
Q
approximately?
A
Approximately what time was this as well,
Approximately 11:00. I don't know. It was
at the end of the night. It had been a long day.
Q
Okay. And can you just give us a sense of
the overall scene? We can see the number of people
here that appear to be watching Mr. Tarrio,
Mr. Nordean, Mr. Stone. But can you give us a sense
from your picture of what the scene was like at this
time?
A
Yes. So there's probably 2-, 300 people.
And it wasn't just Proud Boys. There was a crowd there
for some other reason. I'm not quite sure. We sort of
turned up there.
Q
Do you recall any of the messaging that was
being said at this event?
A
No.
Q
Okay. Do you recall Mr. Tarrio talking about
any communications or interactions you had with
Mr. Stone on December 11?
A
No.
Does anyone have any
follow-up about Mr. Stone in particular before we move
on to the next part of this event? Okay.
BY
Q
So then can we fast forward to the 4:30 mark.
A
I can add one thing.
Q
Yes, please.
A
When I first called Enrique Tarrio's phone,
his answer phone message was Roger Stone saying, This
is Enrique Tarrio's phone. If he's not here, he's out
there kicking ass and doing something good for America.
Q
What were your initial thoughts when you
called Mr. Tarrio and Mr. Stone was the voice on his
voice mail?
A
I thought that was -- I thought it was
like -- first of all, I thought it was one of those
things that you hire people to do. What's that called?
Q
Cameo?
A
Cameo, yeah, I thought he got a cameo,
because Roger Stone -- you know, if you've ever done --
if you've ever been to his website, you can buy
anything from his website, whether it's a Roger Stone,
like a signed stone, which is 25 bucks, or a T-shirt
with "Free Roger Stone," everything revolves around
some type of, you know, merchandise.
Q
And you said that this event took place next
to the Willard. Was that the JW Marriott?
A
Yes. As you can see in the background,
there's Freedom Plaza. And so yes, the JW Marriott,
and then the Willard is one block over, I believe.
Q
Got it. Let's go to the 4:30 mark of this
same exhibit, Exhibit 2, I believe.
(Video played)
BY
Q
Do you know who this individual is speaking
on this part of the video?
A
Is that Owen Shroyer?
Q
Yes.
So do you recall this part of the video when
Mr. Shroyer came up and was next to Mr. Tarrio giving a
speech?
A
Yes.
Q
I guess what, if anything, stood out about
this part of the event?
A
At this point I'm phasing out Owen Shroyer as
much as I can possibly in my life.
Okay. So nothing really stood out to you
Q
about this part?
A
No. It just is a blur of hate and vitriol.
Q
Do you recall Mr. Tarrio saying anything
about Mr. Shroyer after or before this event?
A
No.
Q
During this clip it looks like Mr. Tarrio is
on his phone the entire time. Is that something that
was pretty consistent with Mr. Tarrio, that he was on
his phone?
A
communicator.
Q
Yes. He was a -- he was an avid
And when you say "avid communicator," does
that mean like taking phone calls, texting, internet,
everything?
A
I don't know what he was doing on his phone.
But it was mostly -- it was mostly not to his ear. It
was mostly in his hands.
Q
Okay. Got it. Thank you.
I guess on December 11th, do you know where
the Proud Boys were staying for these events in D.C.?
A
I think that they would split between the
Phoenix Hotel and Harry's, the Harrington Hotel. I
don't think that anyone really wanted to stay -- the
rank and file stayed at the Harrington because it's --
it doesn't have the best reputation as a hotel, shall
we say.
Q
Are you aware of the Proud Boys receiving any
financial assistance to travel and stay in the hotels
in D.C.?
A
No, but I am aware that Enrique Tarrio
traveled by private jet to the -- to several of these
rallies.
Q
Do you know how he was able to procure a
private jet to travel to some of these rallies?
A
I think he was invited by Patrick Byrne.
Q
I guess --
A
And I think Bianca Gracia was on that plane
Q
I guess can you help us, if you can, just
too.
help us understand how you came to that conclusion or
came to that thought.
A
That's subsequent, and that I learned that
subsequently as I've been doing -- we are making a film
about the 64 days, and that was part of our
investigation.
Q
Did you receive any financial assistance from
the Proud Boys or any group to come down to document
December 11th and December 12th?
A
No.
Any follow-up from that?
Seeing no follow-up.
BY
Q
So let's move on to -- actually, before I
move on, did anything else of note happen on
December 11th that I failed to cover?
A
December 11th.
Q
On December 11th? No. I think we covered
All right. So on December 12th when you woke
up that morning, what was the plan for the day?
A
The plan for the day was a late morning walk,
march on the Mall. I think we met, again, at -- I
think we met, again, at the Phoenix, and then walked
across to Harry's, and then walked to the Mall.
Q
Approximately what time was this? You said
11:30. Approximately what time did you meet at the
Phoenix?
A
11:00-ish. I was trying -- Enrique mentioned
that he was going to the White House that morning, and
I did my very best to try and insert myself into that
meeting, which he politely declined.
Q
So you asked Mr. Tarrio if you could go with
him to the White House?
A
Oh, multiple times.
Q
Approximately what time did Mr. Tarrio leave
you to go to the White House?
A
I know he went before the meeting. He went
in the early, early-ish morning.
Can we pull up Exhibit 3,
please, Jacob. Can we scroll down.
BY
Q
So this is a Reuters' article about
Mr. Tarrio's visit to the White House. Unfortunately,
the pictures aren't working on this exhibit, but did
Mr. Tarrio send you any proof or anything that
indicated he was at the White House that morning?
A
Yeah. He sent me a picture of himself in
front of the White House.
Q
And for the record, I believe the picture,
having seen it with Mr. Quested, that Mr. Tarrio sent
is the same photo that matches the Reuters' article of
Mr. Tarrio in front of the White House.
So Mr. Tarrio tours the White House, it
appears that morning. And then you meet up with him
for the first time at around 11:30 that morning?
A
Yes.
Q
And then where did you all go from there?
A
We walked across to Harry's bar, where there
were more Proud Boys, and we walked to the Mall. And,
again, there was another prayer session. There was a
lot more Proud Boys this time. And there was another
speech and another prayer.
And then we probably finished around 2:00.
And we went to get something to eat, and then took a
nap preparing for the evening because we felt that
there was -- you know, we were preparing for the
evening. We felt that there would potentially be a
kinetic situation that evening. They were -- they
feel -- they felt riled up at this point.
Q
So let's break that down a little bit.
You said there were more Proud Boys compared
to the night before, day before. Can you give us an
approximate number difference between the Proud Boys on
December 11th and the Proud Boys on December 12th?
A
Yes. I'd say 100 to 150 on the evening. And
then, I think, 2- to 300, and maybe even more, in the
evening. I could say there were maybe 400 Proud Boys
there.
Q
So how many were on the 11th, just to be
A
I'd say 2- to 300 during the day. And I'd
clear?
say, you know, 400 for the evening. It felt
significantly more people in the evening.
Q
Right. So you're talking about the 12th
right now?
A
Yes.
Q
And then compared to that, how many did you
see on the 11th, the day before?
A
Like 100 to 150.
Q
Thank you.
A
It was a good number, but not -- it swelled.
Q
So on that morning, I know you said you
walked around D.C. Did you all go to Freedom Plaza at
all on December 12?
A
Yes. We went to the speeches on Freedom
Plaza, and Enrique was meant to speak and then didn't
speak, and then we left.
Q
What did he say, if anything, about that
speaking situation, where he was supposed to speak but
didn't speak?
A
He said, It was a shit show and I didn't have
time for this.
Q
Did he say who had coordinated with him to
speak on December 12?
A
No.
Q
Do you recall if the event on December 12th
at Freedom Plaza was the event hosted by Women for
America First?
A
Yes.
Q
So Mr. Tarrio was under the impression that
he would be speaking at the Women for America First
event on December 12?
A
Yes.
Q
You mentioned when we previously talked that
you all also went to a stage hosted by Mr. Dustin
Stockton; is that correct?
A
Oh, yes. Sorry. Yes. We went to that on
the 12th too. I think -- I can't remember if that was
before or after the Freedom Plaza rally.
Q
Where was the stage compared --
A
We also went in Freedom Plaza as the
President flew over in the helicopters. So that's a
time stamp for you.
Q
What was the general feeling of the crowd
when President Trump flew over the Freedom Plaza?
A
There was a wave of excitement.
Q
What was Mr. Tarrio's response to the former
President flying over, if any?
A
Fuck yeah.
Q
Where was Mr. Stockton's stage in comparison
to the Freedom Plaza stage?
A
It was on the other side of the monument.
Q
Approximately how many people were at
Mr. Stockton's stage, if you recall?
A
It was less populated than the Freedom -- the
Freedom Plaza rally was very well attended. There were
lots of people. It was hard to push through the crowd.
It was all sorts of your typical, as I say
typical, but the MAGA community came out in force for
that event. You saw the same -- you see the South
Vietnamese generals with the flags and the T-shirt
shops and the -- there was less of that -- I don't
know, less of the MAGA crowd at the Dustin Stockton
rally on the other side. It was more than a few
people, but it was nicely situated because the
topography worked well for the stage.
So there's a hill that goes up to the
monument, feeds nicely into the stage that was there.
So you could have a lot of people seeing what was going
on without people being too crowded.
Q
Did Mr. Tarrio speak at Mr. Stockton's stage?
A
I don't remember. I think so. And I think
Biggs had a moment too.
Q
Did you all go to any rallies on the Mall as
well on December 12th, like a Jericho March, for
example?
A
No.
Q
And then you said you took a break at some
point in the afternoon; is that correct?
A
Yes.
Q
And you also mentioned that you had a feeling
that individual Proud Boys were resting up because
there might be a kinetic situation that evening on
December 12th?
A
easy. Don't drink too much and we'll see you in the
evening.
Q
That was definitely the plan, was to take it
And who was the kinetic situation going to be
with, from what you could gather?
A
and BLM.
Q
Well, they were preparing to confront Antifa
So I guess walk us through that night then.
What happened? When did you reconnect with the Proud
Boys and what did you all do?
A
I think we reconnected around 7:00 or 8:00 in
the evening. We walked over again from Harry's bar to
the Harrington. There was a big meeting at the
Harrington Hotel. And then we went marching again, and
we went marching towards BLM Plaza.
We walked around the streets, trying to
outflank the police that had come this time in force.
So we would go to the BLM Plaza, and then we would go
around the block. And then -- I know that there was
certain groups of Proud Boys that separated from the
central group, and there were scuffles amongst those
people. But the core group was basically confronting
BLM and shouting over the police at BLM.
Q
What were you thinking as it seems like the
Proud Boys were approaching -- or trying to approach
Black Lives Matter protesters on the evening of
December 12?
A
